I never thought the combination of JRPG elements, turn-based combat, creature collecting (called "Persona"), Persona fusion, and social/dating sim mechanics would be this good. The story is good. The soundtracks is good too.

If you're new to this game series. For the gameplay mechanics sake, I'll recommend Persona 5 Royal first, and then the other mainline Persona games afterwards. There are so many gameplay features that make encountering enemies, etc., much easier (and they're easier to learn/grasp too. So much so that some of these QoL update got brought to the newest Persona 3 Reload and maybe to the upcoming Persona 4 Revival.

For the story continuity sake, I recommend playing it in chronological order, like P3R - P4G/P4R - P5R - P5S. Even better if you could play it from the very 1st Persona game (although that "Old"sona game didn't age well to say the least)

[b]All in all, I really recommend this game.

One thing that always bothered me in the vanilla release was Ryuji’s Rank 7 insta-kill ability—it triggers automatically and ends up getting in the way when you’re trying to farm properly. In Royal, they finally fixed this by letting players choose whether they want to activate it, which feels much more convenient.

The story also gets a few additions that help flesh out the characters and make the narrative flow better. And of course, Persona is known for its outstanding soundtrack—Royal keeps that standard high with music that fits the atmosphere perfectly. The menu design is another highlight; it’s flashy, dynamic, and still manages to stand out compared to its predecessors in the series.

If you enjoy turn-based RPGs or JRPGs in general, I’d absolutely recommend giving Persona 5 Royal a try. It’s a game that genuinely feels worth the purchase.

P5R is a charming and stylish game with a powerful message. The main cast includes the Phantom Thieves, a group of high schoolers who all come from troubled origins and have trauma to overcome. The gameplay can be divided into two main parts. One side of it is the action sequences where the Phantom Thieves explore bizarre mental dimensions called Palaces in an effort to steal a Treasure that will cause criminals and other troublesome people to change their ways and confess to their crimes. The other side is a calmer, realistic life simulation where the player has to manage their time while improving social stats and building connections with their friends.

While I often dislike games that force social connection on you because it usually feels empty or cliched (and some of the social events in P5R definitely *are* cliched), P5R does a great job at presenting compelling social interactions that are also significant for the gameplay, as stronger bonds with your confidants give you enhanced abilities that can be anywhere from mildly helpful to essential for success in the later game.

When I say the social interactions are compelling, I mean that the Phantom Thieves don't feel like poorly written characters. They feel like real high school students and the strife they experience is very well written, with each of them having a unique backstory that establishes their character and makes it so that every player can relate to at least one of them.

From a gameplay perspective, P5R boasts an extensive repertoire of mechanics that may not necessarily make sense intuitively depending on your gaming experience. That said, it does a great job of gradually introducing new things to you, and the difficulty scales gradually over the course of the game in a way that makes your progress and the introduction of new mechanics feel satisfying. Many of these mechanics, in addition to being well designed functionally, are integral to the game's style. For example, the combat features a "one more" feature that allows you to get extra turns after striking an enemy's weakness, but these one mores can then be used as a "baton pass," where that extra turn is given to another member of your party and their attack power is boosted in return. Later in the game, baton passes can be boosted to have various other enhancements.

While these mechanics are good for dramatic flair and they can be fun to play with, the game forces you to make full use of them as you get into the later game missions. Using the baton pass as an example, some of the game's bosses are virtually unbeatable without making heavy use of them, which requires you to have a well balanced party that can exploit a variety of elemental weaknesses. While some people grind early on to soar above the game's difficulty level (which can be freely adjusted throughout the game), I think that playing naturally without grinding produces a fairly well balanced difficulty curve.

The best thing about Persona 5 Royal, however, is its story. Outside of the goofy social situations and the comic book action, a grand tale is being told. From the beginning you're told that the world is facing its impending ruin and that forming connections with others is key to averting that fate. While this sounds fairly generic on the surface, P5R beautifully illustrates its plot in a way that makes you feel encapsulated in every moment, with tension and theatric presentation that I think is unrivaled in other games. The game's central theme revolves around rebellion; fighting against circumstances, oppressors, and even one's own anxieties. And the antagonists that the Phantom Thieves face range from mundane people who only have local influence over the cast, to national and even otherworldly threats.

This is a long game. I just finished my first playthrough at nearly 128 hours. That said, the game doesn't expect you to rush or make great strides of progress in short periods of time. In fact, much of the gameplay revolves around a calendar system that encourages players to slow down and make thoughtful use of their time. The game also has built in features to review information about your confidants and the plot in case you forget anything after a break (though in my case I was never taking breaks lol).

The game also has a fairly active modding scene. For my second playthrough I'm planning on playing a story overhaul mod that changes the MC and makes various other improvements.

Lastly, Persona's soundtrack is genuinely unparalleled. There isn't a single song in this game that I couldn't listen to for an hour straight, or in the case of some songs, many hours straight. The game combines instrumental music with some vocalized songs that form the backbone of the game's emotional appeal. I think this game's music is some of the best and I think it ties together the game's tone perfectly.

Needless to say, I couldn't recommend this game enough. The only thing I'd warn you about is that once you start playing this game, there might be no way back for you! I was hooked for over a month on this game, it quickly usurping my free time from all my other hobbies. It's the kind of game that you wish you could experience again for the first time. I encourage you to go in blind and enjoy the game at your own pace. It's the kind of experience you'll never forget.

[b]Game is a glorified VN.[/b]

Persona 5 has stylish presentation and solid turn-based combat, but the game barely lets you play it. Every time you finish a dungeon, the game forces you into long stretches of dialogue, calendar events, and slice-of-life filler before you’re allowed to have real gameplay again. The pacing constantly kills any momentum the game builds.

[h2]Dialogue, Fake Choices & Relationship Points[/h2]

If it wasn’t for the fake multiple-choice sections, your controller would probably turn itself off. Most of the time you pick an option, get one line of flavor text, and then the game snaps right back to the same scripted dialogue. Every now and then you get a funny line that feels like you're making your own moment in an anime, but those are rare.

You can also get those little blue musical-note boosts that increase your bond with characters. I looked this up online, and from what people say, having a Persona of the same Arcana gives you extra points. But the whole thing is pretty inconsistent — the number of notes you see doesn’t always match how many points you actually got. Sometimes you even hit the “max notes” but it still isn’t enough to rank up. It makes the system feel vague and kind of pointless unless you're following a guide.

[h2]Gameplay Pacing Issues[/h2]

• Long stretches with no combat
• Forced downtime after every dungeon
• JRPG gameplay comes in short bursts
• Momentum is constantly interrupted

Every time I finally got control back, I would rush through the entire dungeon in a single session because I was starving for actual gameplay. After that, the game locks me out again and makes me wait through 20+ in-game days before the next real segment.

[h2]Side Content Problems[/h2]

Mementos is recycled content with weak minibosses and no real payoff. Social links / confidants can be interesting, but many of them drag on or repeat themes, relying heavily on dialogue that doesn’t meaningfully impact the story or game mechanics.

[h2]Overall[/h2]

Persona 5 is good — the combat is fun, the style is polished, and the writing can hit emotional notes. But make no mistake: it is a visual novel first and foremost, and only sometimes a JRPG. If you want gameplay to be the core of your experience, this structure is likely to feel restrictive, slow, and frustrating.

[b]Not recommended for gameplay-first JRPG players.[/b]

Bought it during a sale a long time ago and finally decided to give it a try. I came into it after hearing about how it's the greatest thing ever from both the community and some friends and with an overwhelmingly positive score I had really high hopes. I like to put in a good amount of hours into something or try to finish it before giving it a review but I just couldn't do the latter. For some context i've played various tales series games (berseria, vesperia, symphonia and abyss), i've played metaphor refantazio (still need to beat that one),  paper mario, etc. so i'm not at all new to the genre of anime or turn based. My thoughts:

[h1] Overall 6.5/10 [/h1]
 [h2] Gameplay 8/10 [/h2]
        So having played this game I originally thought the gameplay was 10/10 but after playing Expedition 33, it's knocked it down. you could say it's unfair since it's an older game and I would agree but that's just kinda how evolution goes and hopefully Persona 6 gets even better. Anyway the combat system is very fluid and fun and with the ability to chain combos / stuns with the different characters it feels very engaging. The mechanic of fusing your personas to create stronger ones was implemented very well and the amount of combinations feels endless. I enjoyed the aspect of choosing what you want to do with your day and it felt very rewarding with an almost "majora's mask" vibe as the end date got closer. Overall the gameplay is honestly very good but like I said earlier expedition 33 just nails the combat sections, while metaphor refantazio does the activity sections better. Although the fusion of personas is still something I very much enjoyed I look forward to what they will do going forward with Persona 6.

[h2] Story 5/10 [/h2]
       The Majority of characters are bland or flat out annoying while few others are pretty enjoyable. This game suffers from a mediocre script at best with several dialogue or voice lines being repeated nonstop. The beginning of the story just doesn't make sense to me as it seems very dramatized for the sake of creating a problem. Granted a lot of stories do that, but in the context of "real world" problems that it's trying to emulate, it just doesn't seem like a plausible outcome. i know it's an anime game and it's stoked up to 11 but the adults in the game just seem incompetent or douchy for no reason. In defense of kamoshida (who is your first boss) he's taken over by evil so it makes sense he's an irredeemable jerk, but it just doesn't make sense for other characters like the parents, police, or other staff unless it's part of further plot I never managed to see. explained slightly more in conclusion. If you don't mind the trope of incompetent adults then it's probably more enjoyable but I feel like that trope should be reserved for something that is not trying to emulate real world issues.

[h2] Graphics / Visuals / Music 15/10 [/h2]
         I just love the art style and visual aspects of the game, not to mention the soundtrack. it's immediately recognizable and memorable without being annoying because it's just the right amount of over the top. character designs, VFX, and ambience is a homerun. I think everyone can agree that it's easily the best aspect of the game without much need for explanation. 

[h2] Performance 10/10 [/h2]
      It's an older game with a remaster so unless you have a potato it will run. No bugs or issues ever encountered during a casual playthrough. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
      It may be kinda confusing how the game sounds amazing despite the story and the fact I couldn't finish it. My gripe with the game is the sheer amount of handholding it does. depending on the starting difficulty you set yourself on the tutorial, it alone is estimated around 8 HOURS or maybe ~10 hours on hard mode. I get that there is quite a lot of mechanics with some being very complex but it doesn't need to be 8 hours. A majority of the mechanics you can just figure out naturally or learn later as you play, but the game insists on having you learn 1 or 2 mechanics and then completing the instance or Palace. You then go back to the Palace to learn 1 more mechanic and in doing so you basically just unlock a pea sized section more of the Palace. You then essentially repeat that while back tracking until the game deems you worthy of actually being able to play. It gets better, because even if you can play the game now, it will still hold your hand. The amount of "babying" this game does is atrocious and after reading articles on reddit and steam it seems it persists until the 3rd palace. I managed to beat the first Palace aka Kamoshida but I highly recommend watching a let's play before buying the game to see if you actually want to play it. Persona 5 is a heavily narrative game with an absurd amount of handholding so it's probably best to just watch someone else play it.

[b]Game is a glorified VN.[/b]

Persona 5 has stylish presentation and solid turn-based combat, but the game barely lets you play it. Every time you finish a dungeon, the game forces you into long stretches of dialogue, calendar events, and slice-of-life filler before you’re allowed to have real gameplay again. The pacing constantly kills any momentum the game builds.

[h2]Dialogue, Fake Choices & Relationship Points[/h2]

If it wasn’t for the fake multiple-choice sections, your controller would probably turn itself off. Most of the time you pick an option, get one line of flavor text, and then the game snaps right back to the same scripted dialogue. Every now and then you get a funny line that feels like you're making your own moment in an anime, but those are rare.

You can also get those little blue musical-note boosts that increase your bond with characters. I looked this up online, and from what people say, having a Persona of the same Arcana gives you extra points. But the whole thing is pretty inconsistent — the number of notes you see doesn’t always match how many points you actually got. Sometimes you even hit the “max notes” but it still isn’t enough to rank up. It makes the system feel vague and kind of pointless unless you're following a guide.

[h2]Gameplay Pacing Issues[/h2]

• Long stretches with no combat
• Forced downtime after every dungeon
• JRPG gameplay comes in short bursts
• Momentum is constantly interrupted

Every time I finally got control back, I would rush through the entire dungeon in a single session because I was starving for actual gameplay. After that, the game locks me out again and makes me wait through 20+ in-game days before the next real segment.

[h2]Side Content Problems[/h2]

Mementos is recycled content with weak minibosses and no real payoff. Social links / confidants can be interesting, but many of them drag on or repeat themes, relying heavily on dialogue that doesn’t meaningfully impact the story or game mechanics.

[h2]Overall[/h2]

Persona 5 is good — the combat is fun, the style is polished, and the writing can hit emotional notes. But make no mistake: it is a visual novel first and foremost, and only sometimes a JRPG. If you want gameplay to be the core of your experience, this structure is likely to feel restrictive, slow, and frustrating.

[b]Not recommended for gameplay-first JRPG players.[/b]

Bought it during a sale a long time ago and finally decided to give it a try. I came into it after hearing about how it's the greatest thing ever from both the community and some friends and with an overwhelmingly positive score I had really high hopes. I like to put in a good amount of hours into something or try to finish it before giving it a review but I just couldn't do the latter. For some context i've played various tales series games (berseria, vesperia, symphonia and abyss), i've played metaphor refantazio (still need to beat that one),  paper mario, etc. so i'm not at all new to the genre of anime or turn based. My thoughts:

[h1] Overall 6.5/10 [/h1]
 [h2] Gameplay 8/10 [/h2]
        So having played this game I originally thought the gameplay was 10/10 but after playing Expedition 33, it's knocked it down. you could say it's unfair since it's an older game and I would agree but that's just kinda how evolution goes and hopefully Persona 6 gets even better. Anyway the combat system is very fluid and fun and with the ability to chain combos / stuns with the different characters it feels very engaging. The mechanic of fusing your personas to create stronger ones was implemented very well and the amount of combinations feels endless. I enjoyed the aspect of choosing what you want to do with your day and it felt very rewarding with an almost "majora's mask" vibe as the end date got closer. Overall the gameplay is honestly very good but like I said earlier expedition 33 just nails the combat sections, while metaphor refantazio does the activity sections better. Although the fusion of personas is still something I very much enjoyed I look forward to what they will do going forward with Persona 6.

[h2] Story 5/10 [/h2]
       The Majority of characters are bland or flat out annoying while few others are pretty enjoyable. This game suffers from a mediocre script at best with several dialogue or voice lines being repeated nonstop. The beginning of the story just doesn't make sense to me as it seems very dramatized for the sake of creating a problem. Granted a lot of stories do that, but in the context of "real world" problems that it's trying to emulate, it just doesn't seem like a plausible outcome. i know it's an anime game and it's stoked up to 11 but the adults in the game just seem incompetent or douchy for no reason. In defense of kamoshida (who is your first boss) he's taken over by evil so it makes sense he's an irredeemable jerk, but it just doesn't make sense for other characters like the parents, police, or other staff unless it's part of further plot I never managed to see. explained slightly more in conclusion. If you don't mind the trope of incompetent adults then it's probably more enjoyable but I feel like that trope should be reserved for something that is not trying to emulate real world issues.

[h2] Graphics / Visuals / Music 15/10 [/h2]
         I just love the art style and visual aspects of the game, not to mention the soundtrack. it's immediately recognizable and memorable without being annoying because it's just the right amount of over the top. character designs, VFX, and ambience is a homerun. I think everyone can agree that it's easily the best aspect of the game without much need for explanation. 

[h2] Performance 10/10 [/h2]
      It's an older game with a remaster so unless you have a potato it will run. No bugs or issues ever encountered during a casual playthrough. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
      It may be kinda confusing how the game sounds amazing despite the story and the fact I couldn't finish it. My gripe with the game is the sheer amount of handholding it does. depending on the starting difficulty you set yourself on the tutorial, it alone is estimated around 8 HOURS or maybe ~10 hours on hard mode. I get that there is quite a lot of mechanics with some being very complex but it doesn't need to be 8 hours. A majority of the mechanics you can just figure out naturally or learn later as you play, but the game insists on having you learn 1 or 2 mechanics and then completing the instance or Palace. You then go back to the Palace to learn 1 more mechanic and in doing so you basically just unlock a pea sized section more of the Palace. You then essentially repeat that while back tracking until the game deems you worthy of actually being able to play. It gets better, because even if you can play the game now, it will still hold your hand. The amount of "babying" this game does is atrocious and after reading articles on reddit and steam it seems it persists until the 3rd palace. I managed to beat the first Palace aka Kamoshida but I highly recommend watching a let's play before buying the game to see if you actually want to play it. Persona 5 is a heavily narrative game with an absurd amount of handholding so it's probably best to just watch someone else play it.

[b]Game is a glorified VN.[/b]

Persona 5 has stylish presentation and solid turn-based combat, but the game barely lets you play it. Every time you finish a dungeon, the game forces you into long stretches of dialogue, calendar events, and slice-of-life filler before you’re allowed to have real gameplay again. The pacing constantly kills any momentum the game builds.

[h2]Dialogue, Fake Choices & Relationship Points[/h2]

If it wasn’t for the fake multiple-choice sections, your controller would probably turn itself off. Most of the time you pick an option, get one line of flavor text, and then the game snaps right back to the same scripted dialogue. Every now and then you get a funny line that feels like you're making your own moment in an anime, but those are rare.

You can also get those little blue musical-note boosts that increase your bond with characters. I looked this up online, and from what people say, having a Persona of the same Arcana gives you extra points. But the whole thing is pretty inconsistent — the number of notes you see doesn’t always match how many points you actually got. Sometimes you even hit the “max notes” but it still isn’t enough to rank up. It makes the system feel vague and kind of pointless unless you're following a guide.

[h2]Gameplay Pacing Issues[/h2]

• Long stretches with no combat
• Forced downtime after every dungeon
• JRPG gameplay comes in short bursts
• Momentum is constantly interrupted

Every time I finally got control back, I would rush through the entire dungeon in a single session because I was starving for actual gameplay. After that, the game locks me out again and makes me wait through 20+ in-game days before the next real segment.

[h2]Side Content Problems[/h2]

Mementos is recycled content with weak minibosses and no real payoff. Social links / confidants can be interesting, but many of them drag on or repeat themes, relying heavily on dialogue that doesn’t meaningfully impact the story or game mechanics.

[h2]Overall[/h2]

Persona 5 is good — the combat is fun, the style is polished, and the writing can hit emotional notes. But make no mistake: it is a visual novel first and foremost, and only sometimes a JRPG. If you want gameplay to be the core of your experience, this structure is likely to feel restrictive, slow, and frustrating.

[b]Not recommended for gameplay-first JRPG players.[/b]

Bought it during a sale a long time ago and finally decided to give it a try. I came into it after hearing about how it's the greatest thing ever from both the community and some friends and with an overwhelmingly positive score I had really high hopes. I like to put in a good amount of hours into something or try to finish it before giving it a review but I just couldn't do the latter. For some context i've played various tales series games (berseria, vesperia, symphonia and abyss), i've played metaphor refantazio (still need to beat that one),  paper mario, etc. so i'm not at all new to the genre of anime or turn based. My thoughts:

[h1] Overall 6.5/10 [/h1]
 [h2] Gameplay 8/10 [/h2]
        So having played this game I originally thought the gameplay was 10/10 but after playing Expedition 33, it's knocked it down. you could say it's unfair since it's an older game and I would agree but that's just kinda how evolution goes and hopefully Persona 6 gets even better. Anyway the combat system is very fluid and fun and with the ability to chain combos / stuns with the different characters it feels very engaging. The mechanic of fusing your personas to create stronger ones was implemented very well and the amount of combinations feels endless. I enjoyed the aspect of choosing what you want to do with your day and it felt very rewarding with an almost "majora's mask" vibe as the end date got closer. Overall the gameplay is honestly very good but like I said earlier expedition 33 just nails the combat sections, while metaphor refantazio does the activity sections better. Although the fusion of personas is still something I very much enjoyed I look forward to what they will do going forward with Persona 6.

[h2] Story 5/10 [/h2]
       The Majority of characters are bland or flat out annoying while few others are pretty enjoyable. This game suffers from a mediocre script at best with several dialogue or voice lines being repeated nonstop. The beginning of the story just doesn't make sense to me as it seems very dramatized for the sake of creating a problem. Granted a lot of stories do that, but in the context of "real world" problems that it's trying to emulate, it just doesn't seem like a plausible outcome. i know it's an anime game and it's stoked up to 11 but the adults in the game just seem incompetent or douchy for no reason. In defense of kamoshida (who is your first boss) he's taken over by evil so it makes sense he's an irredeemable jerk, but it just doesn't make sense for other characters like the parents, police, or other staff unless it's part of further plot I never managed to see. explained slightly more in conclusion. If you don't mind the trope of incompetent adults then it's probably more enjoyable but I feel like that trope should be reserved for something that is not trying to emulate real world issues.

[h2] Graphics / Visuals / Music 15/10 [/h2]
         I just love the art style and visual aspects of the game, not to mention the soundtrack. it's immediately recognizable and memorable without being annoying because it's just the right amount of over the top. character designs, VFX, and ambience is a homerun. I think everyone can agree that it's easily the best aspect of the game without much need for explanation. 

[h2] Performance 10/10 [/h2]
      It's an older game with a remaster so unless you have a potato it will run. No bugs or issues ever encountered during a casual playthrough. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
      It may be kinda confusing how the game sounds amazing despite the story and the fact I couldn't finish it. My gripe with the game is the sheer amount of handholding it does. depending on the starting difficulty you set yourself on the tutorial, it alone is estimated around 8 HOURS or maybe ~10 hours on hard mode. I get that there is quite a lot of mechanics with some being very complex but it doesn't need to be 8 hours. A majority of the mechanics you can just figure out naturally or learn later as you play, but the game insists on having you learn 1 or 2 mechanics and then completing the instance or Palace. You then go back to the Palace to learn 1 more mechanic and in doing so you basically just unlock a pea sized section more of the Palace. You then essentially repeat that while back tracking until the game deems you worthy of actually being able to play. It gets better, because even if you can play the game now, it will still hold your hand. The amount of "babying" this game does is atrocious and after reading articles on reddit and steam it seems it persists until the 3rd palace. I managed to beat the first Palace aka Kamoshida but I highly recommend watching a let's play before buying the game to see if you actually want to play it. Persona 5 is a heavily narrative game with an absurd amount of handholding so it's probably best to just watch someone else play it.
